name: 無線通訊
goals: Study different topics such as wireless system theory, fundamental frequency signal processing, communication protocols, etc.
Analyze the performance of different wireless communication systems
Emphasis on the integration and application of wireless system theory
Understand the design and development of modern communication systems
Obtain the research ability of wireless communication systems
syllabus:
This course will cover following topics in wireless communication for voice, data, and multimedia. It begins with an overview of current wireless systems and standards. It then characterizes the wireless channel, including path loss for different environments, shadowing, and multipath fading. It then examines the capacity limitations and transmission strategies of wireless channels. The next focus will be multicarrier techniques to combat frequency-selective fading and discussing various practical multiple access schemes in wireless systems. The next part of the course is looking over wireless networking and course concludes with discussing different wireless systems and current standards.

Tentative Course Syllabus (\*Subject to changes)

Week 1: Overview and History of Wireless Communications

Week 2: Radio Propagation Models

Week 3: Signal Fading Statistics

Week 4: Propagation Path-loss Models

Week 5: Frequency Reuse and Channel Assignment Strategies

Week 6: Handoff Strategies and System Capacity

Week 7: Midterm

Week 8: Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA)

Week 9: Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA)

Week 10: Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA)

Week 11: Space Diversion and Carrier Sense Multiple Access (SDMA and CSMA)

Week 12: Traffic Routing in Wireless Networks

Week 13: Wireless Network Managements

Week 14: Wireless LAN: IEEE 802.11

Week 15: Global System for Mobile (GSM) and CDMA Digital Cellular Standard (IS-95)

Week 16: Final Exam

Week 17: Opt. Class (1)

Week 18: Opt. Class (2)

methodologies.note: Weekly class lecture with homework assignment. As a teacher, my responsibility is to convey what is known to students and motivate them to probe what is unknown.
